book_summary.book_title: Venture Deals: Be Smarter Than Your Lawyer and Venture Capitalist
book_summary.overall_summary:
Venture Deals demystifies the opaque language, incentives, and documents that govern venture capital financings and startup fundraising. The book opens by mapping the human and institutional players — entrepreneurs, angels, lead and follow-on VCs, syndicates, and lawyers — and explains how their differing incentives and authority shape the contours of every deal. From this foundation it defines the term sheet as the central negotiating vehicle and frames the negotiation around two core levers: economics (who owns what) and control (who makes the decisions).

From there the authors walk readers clause by clause through typical term-sheet provisions: valuation and price mechanics, liquidation preferences and participation, option pool sizing, vesting and acceleration, antidilution protection, board composition and protective provisions, registration and information rights, and conversion triggers. Interwoven throughout are entrepreneur-focused sidebars that translate legal mechanics into pragmatic negotiating posture — what to fight over, what to accept, and how to create leverage in the fundraising process.

The book then moves to concrete, hands-on tools: cap table math with worked examples demonstrating pre-money vs. post-money effects and how a post-money option pool can materially dilute founders; an explanation of convertible debt instruments (notes, caps, discounts, SAFEs/KISS) and the traps and tradeoffs they create; and a short legal primer on employment, corporate form, and the critical 83(b) election entrepreneurs must not forget. Each technical chapter emphasizes transparency, clear documentation, and understanding the downstream consequences of seemingly small term-sheet choices.

Finally, Venture Deals widens its lens to ecosystem dynamics, arguing that places that produce startups do so because of long-term, entrepreneur-led community building (the Boulder Thesis). Throughout, the book’s practical aim is constant: to give founders and new investors the vocabulary, mental models, and numeric skills to negotiate better, avoid common legal and financial pitfalls, and design financings that preserve upside while aligning incentives for follow-on growth and exit.
key_themes: Economics vs. control: the two fundamental levers in any term sheet
Transparency and education: demystifying VC language to level the negotiating field
Practical, clause-level literacy: knowing which terms materially affect value and governance
Founders’ protection and alignment: preserving upside while attracting institutional capital
Rigorous math and cap table hygiene: precise calculations matter
Legal fundamentals: employment, corporate form, and tax steps (83(b))
Community and ecosystem building: place matters for startup success (Boulder Thesis)
learning_objectives: Understand the roles, incentives, and decision-making authority of all players in a venture financing
Read and negotiate a term sheet with clarity on economics (valuation, preferences, option pool) and control (board seats, protective provisions)
Build and audit cap tables accurately to model dilution and price-per-share consequences
Evaluate convertible instruments (notes, SAFEs) including discounts, caps, maturity, and conversion mechanics
Identify and avoid common legal pitfalls (employment issues, entity choice, 83(b) elections) that can damage value

Chapter 1, "The Players," maps the human and institutional landscape that underpins every venture transaction. It profiles the core participants — the entrepreneur who needs capital and control, the venture capitalist (VC) whose incentives are shaped by fund structure and limited partners, angel investors who often seed early-stage companies, syndicates that spread risk and expertise across investors, and the lawyers and mentors who guide both process and substance. The chapter explains financing-round nomenclature and types of VC firms so readers can distinguish between seed, early-stage, and later-stage players and understand why different investors bring different expectations about governance, dilution, and exit timing.

Building on the Introduction’s framing of the "art of the term sheet," this chapter shows that term-sheet economics and control provisions are driven as much by who is on the table as by legal form. It emphasizes practical dynamics — how a lead VC differs from passive syndicate members, why entrepreneurs should target the right type of firm, how angels can bridge the gap to institutional capital, and how counsel and mentors influence deal timing, diligence, and negotiation posture. By anchoring later technical chapters (on liquidation preferences, board composition, antidilution, etc.) in the real motivations and roles of these players, the chapter sets the stage for strategic fundraising and informed bargaining.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

with their lawyers, came up with structures that made sense to them.
They then developed a shorthand so that they could communicate
among themselves.

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals
is foreign to many and remains opaque and confusing to this day.
This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

Fred Wilson
USV Partner
July 2016

The Foreword and Preface set the tone for the rest of the book: venture capital is full of specialized language and opaque practices that can bewilder entrepreneurs new to the space. Fred Wilson’s Foreword underlines this with a personal anecdote about learning what “pre-money” meant and highlights the value of transparency — pointing readers to accessible resources (blogs and the book Venture Deals) that demystify deal language. The message is clear: understanding VC terminology and mechanics matters and is learnable.

The Preface explains why the authors wrote the book, tracing its origin to a popular Term Sheet blog series and an ongoing desire to create a practical, balanced guide for entrepreneurs and investors. It summarizes the book’s structure — from a history of the term sheet and profiles of participants, to practical guidance on how much to raise and what documents to prepare, deep dives into term-sheet economics, control and miscellaneous terms, convertible debt versus equity, a new section on crowdfunding, how VC firms operate (incentives and compensation), negotiation strategy, acquisition letters of intent, and common legal issues. The authors emphasize a balanced viewpoint (entrepreneur and VC), include sidebars with an entrepreneur’s perspective, and aim to make complex deal mechanics accessible and actionable.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Overview of the Term Sheet

A
t the end of 2005, during the dark ages when venture capital was
very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much
more difficult than it needed to be. All of the participants were to
blame, and ignorance of what really mattered in the negotiation
kept things going much longer than was necessary. We talked about
what to do and, at the risk of giving away super-top-secret venture
capital magic tricks, decided to write a blog series on Brad's blog
(Feld Thoughts-www.feld.com) that deconstructed a venture capital
term sheet and explained each section.

That blog series was the inspiration for this book. The next few
chapters cover the most frequently discussed terms in a venture capi-
tal term sheet. Many venture capitalists (VCs) love to negotiate hard
on every term as though the health of their children depended on
them getting the terms just right. Sometimes this is inexperience on
the part of the VC; often, it's just a negotiating tactic.

The specific language that we refer to is from actual term sheets.
In addition to describing and explaining the specific terms, we give
you examples of what to focus on and implications from the perspec-
tives of the company, VCs, and entrepreneurs.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 5 moves from the framing and players introduced earlier (Foreword, Preface, and Chapter 4) into a practical, clause-by-clause overview of what actually matters in a venture term sheet. The authors distill VC priorities into two core lenses—economics and control—and then walk through the most common economic terms (price/valuation, liquidation preference and participation, pay-to-play, option pool and warrants, vesting and exercise periods, dividends, redemption rights, and antidilution mechanics) and the key control terms (board composition, protective provisions, conversion and automatic conversion thresholds). Each term is explained in plain language, with examples of how the provision affects distribution of proceeds, voting power, incentives, and downstream negotiations.

The chapter emphasizes negotiation priorities and entrepreneur-centered tactics: don’t focus only on headline valuation; prepare an option budget before the option-pool fight; understand how warrants or back-door mechanisms effectively lower valuation; negotiate the type and scope of antidilution (broad-based weighted average preferred to full ratchet); favor double-trigger acceleration for vesting; equalize automatic-conversion thresholds across series to avoid a veto by later investors; and watch the conditions precedent and binding clauses (legal fees, no-shop, governing law). Practical sidebars reinforce when a term is mostly theoretical versus when it will materially affect founder equity or company control, and they advise entrepreneurs where to spend negotiating energy.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 6 adopts the entrepreneur’s point of view and delivers practical rules of thumb for protecting founders during the term-sheet phase. The chapter’s headline advice is simple but crucial: if a term sheet contains a no-shop (exclusivity) clause, insist that all key items—especially employment, compensation, and board-related terms—be spelled out before you sign. A VC who refuses to document core employment terms up front is a serious red flag. The authors emphasize that entrepreneurs should not be locked into exclusivity without clarity on the operative business and people terms that will govern the definitive agreements.

The chapter also cautions that term sheets sometimes carry odd or highly conditional language—“wacky conditions”—and it reminds founders that signing a term sheet is not the same as closing a deal. Building on the earlier—chapter 4’s mapping of players and mechanics and chapter 5’s clause-by-clause walkthrough of economics and control—this chapter translates technical knowledge into negotiation posture: demand clarity, watch for binding/no-shop traps, and treat any unusual conditions with skepticism. In short, understand which provisions are binding, insist on spelling out the deal points that matter to you before exclusivity kicks in, and recognize that a signed term sheet does not guarantee a completed financing.

The Entrepreneur's Perspective

If you care about information rights for your shareholders, you are nuts. You
should run a transparent organization as much as possible in the twenty-first
century. If you can't commit to sending your shareholders a budget and financial
statements, you shouldn't take on outside investors. If you are of the paranoid
mindset (which I generally applaud), feel free to insist on a strict confidentiality
clause to accompany your information rights.
chapter_summaries.summary:
This chapter adopts the entrepreneur’s point of view on information rights and ongoing reporting obligations that commonly appear in term sheets and investor agreements. Building on the earlier, clause-by-clause framing of venture deals, it argues that entrepreneurs should embrace transparency as a default: if you plan to take outside capital you should be prepared to deliver a budget and regular financial statements to your investors. At the same time, the chapter recognizes founder instincts to protect proprietary details and recommends pairing routine information rights with tailored confidentiality protections so sensitive data does not leak or get misused.

The chapter places these recommendations in practical terms: information rights are not just an administrative burden but a signal of professionalism and a foundation for a productive investor-founder relationship. Entrepreneurs should negotiate scope, frequency, and format so reporting is meaningful without being crushing, and insist on confidentiality clauses when particularly sensitive operational or strategic information is involved. In short, welcome transparency to build trust, but use reasonable limits and contractual protections to preserve competitive advantage and operational flexibility.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 8 shifts the point of view fully onto the entrepreneur’s long‑term upside and exit mindset, building on the clause-level mechanics of Chapter 5 and the founder protections emphasized in Chapters 6 and 7. Rather than diving into registration rights minutiae, the chapter argues entrepreneurs should prioritize structuring the company and the deal to maximize eventual public market value — keeping optionality open for an IPO, aligning investor incentives toward a high‑value exit, and avoiding short‑term provisions that erode upside. Practical recommendations include managing dilution, preserving pro rata participation, planning for pre‑IPO housekeeping (cap table cleanliness, corporate governance), and understanding how lock‑ups, secondary sales, and conversion mechanics affect public market prospects.

The chapter connects tactical negotiation points to the strategic goal of going public: control and economic tradeoffs (the lenses from Chapter 5) must be weighed not only for today’s round but for the path to a successful IPO. It reiterates earlier advice about transparency and investor alignment (from Chapter 7) and founder protections during term-sheet negotiation (from Chapter 6), but reframes those as instruments to preserve upside. The bottom line: registration rights are a backstop, not the main game — entrepreneurs should design financing and governance to keep the company attractive to public investors and to retain as much capture of future value as possible.

Chapter 9 reframes the sale-restriction debate from the entrepreneur’s point of view, arguing that the restriction on sales (the right of first refusal on common stock, or ROFR on common) is generally constructive rather than punitive. The chapter defines the typical clause, recommends placing it in the bylaws for clarity and enforceability, and explains the common implementation practice of allowing the company to exercise the ROFR and then assign that right to investors. It traces the historical shift—from an older orthodoxy that prevented founders from selling until investors could exit, to the modern reality of active secondaries and longer private-company lifecycles—and concludes that ROFRs help the company control its shareholder base and comply with heightened SEC scrutiny around private transfers.

Building on earlier, clause-level discussions, the chapter gives practical entrepreneur-focused advice: don’t fight a ROFR wholesale, but make it precise. Define who qualifies as a "major investor" (so that minor or passive holders don’t gain blanket transfer control), and consider conditioning transferee rights on continued participation in subsequent financing rounds. These limits protect founders’ liquidity options while preserving the company’s ability to manage its cap table, align investor incentives, and keep downstream regulatory and governance issues manageable.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. While this is close enough for an example, it's not close enough for most VCs, or for most lawyers for that matter. And it shouldn't be close enough for you. As the entrepreneur, you shouldn't blindly rely on legal counsel to generate these documents. There are a lot of good lawyers out there with poor math skills, and the cap table can get messed up when left in the hands of the lawyers. chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

Chapter 15 moves from firm-level mechanics (term sheets, cap tables, convertible notes, and legal traps discussed in earlier chapters) to the place-level question: why do some places become hotbeds of startups while others do not? The chapter surveys three academic frameworks (economic agglomeration/external economies, sociology, and geography) that explain the clustering of innovation and then introduces a fourth, practice-driven framework — the Boulder Thesis — distilled from local experience. The Boulder Thesis argues that vibrant startup communities are entrepreneur-led, require long-term commitments, must be inclusive, and need ongoing activities that engage the entire entrepreneurial stack.

The chapter emphasizes the importance of a multi-decade view: community leaders must commit for the long haul (the author suggests a 20-year horizon) because startup ecosystems go through booms and busts and meaningful outcomes take time. It also stresses practical community-building: frequent, hands-on activities (hackathons, meetups, startup weekends, accelerators) that actively involve first-time and experienced founders, investors, mentors, employees, and service providers are far more impactful than occasional networking or awards events. Finally, the chapter normalizes experimentation and failure in community programs — like startups themselves, some activities will fail and should be replaced — and underscores inclusivity and continuous engagement as core to sustained entrepreneurial vitality.

data.overall_summary:
Venture Deals demystifies the opaque language, incentives, and documents that govern venture capital financings and startup fundraising. The book opens by mapping the human and institutional players — entrepreneurs, angels, lead and follow-on VCs, syndicates, and lawyers — and explains how their differing incentives and authority shape the contours of every deal. From this foundation it defines the term sheet as the central negotiating vehicle and frames the negotiation around two core levers: economics (who owns what) and control (who makes the decisions).

From there the authors walk readers clause by clause through typical term-sheet provisions: valuation and price mechanics, liquidation preferences and participation, option pool sizing, vesting and acceleration, antidilution protection, board composition and protective provisions, registration and information rights, and conversion triggers. Interwoven throughout are entrepreneur-focused sidebars that translate legal mechanics into pragmatic negotiating posture — what to fight over, what to accept, and how to create leverage in the fundraising process.

The book then moves to concrete, hands-on tools: cap table math with worked examples demonstrating pre-money vs. post-money effects and how a post-money option pool can materially dilute founders; an explanation of convertible debt instruments (notes, caps, discounts, SAFEs/KISS) and the traps and tradeoffs they create; and a short legal primer on employment, corporate form, and the critical 83(b) election entrepreneurs must not forget. Each technical chapter emphasizes transparency, clear documentation, and understanding the downstream consequences of seemingly small term-sheet choices.

Finally, Venture Deals widens its lens to ecosystem dynamics, arguing that places that produce startups do so because of long-term, entrepreneur-led community building (the Boulder Thesis). Throughout, the book’s practical aim is constant: to give founders and new investors the vocabulary, mental models, and numeric skills to negotiate better, avoid common legal and financial pitfalls, and design financings that preserve upside while aligning incentives for follow-on growth and exit.

Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

They then developed a shorthand so that they could communicate

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals
is foreign to many and remains opaque and confusing to this day.
This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

Fred Wilson
USV Partner

Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

Building on the book’s opening discussions about terminology and opaque practices, it shows that while term sheets have become longer and more detailed over time, the real negotiation centers on two core axes: economics (who owns what) and control (who makes the decisions). The chapter then unpacks the human and institutional cast—VC hierarchy (MD/GP, partners, principals, associates, analysts, venture/operating partners, EIRs), angels/super angels/micro-VCs, syndicates and lead investors, and lawyers—and explains how their incentives, authority, and behavior affect every stage of a deal.

Emphases include choosing an experienced VC-savvy lawyer, focusing on the demo and concise materials, understanding who in a firm actually has decision power, and treating fundraising as a strategic, time-consuming process where choice and timing create negotiating power.

Chapter 5 moves from the framing and players introduced earlier (Foreword, Preface, and Chapter 4) into a practical, clause-by-clause overview of what actually matters in a venture term sheet. The authors distill VC priorities into two core lenses—economics and control—and then walk through the most common economic terms (price/valuation, liquidation preference and participation, pay-to-play, option pool and warrants, vesting and exercise periods, dividends, redemption rights, and antidilution mechanics) and the key control terms (board composition, protective provisions, conversion and automatic conversion thresholds). Each term is explained in plain language, with examples of how the provision affects distribution of proceeds, voting power, incentives, and downstream negotiations.

The chapter emphasizes negotiation priorities and entrepreneur-centered tactics: don’t focus only on headline valuation; prepare an option budget before the option-pool fight; understand how warrants or back-door mechanisms effectively lower valuation; negotiate the type and scope of antidilution (broad-based weighted average preferred to full ratchet); favor double-trigger acceleration for vesting; equalize automatic-conversion thresholds across series to avoid a veto by later investors; and watch the conditions precedent and binding clauses (legal fees, no-shop, governing law). Practical sidebars reinforce when a term is mostly theoretical versus when it will materially affect founder equity or company control, and they advise entrepreneurs where to spend negotiating energy.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 6 adopts the entrepreneur’s point of view and delivers practical rules of thumb for protecting founders during the term-sheet phase. The chapter’s headline advice is simple but crucial: if a term sheet contains a no-shop (exclusivity) clause, insist that all key items—especially employment, compensation, and board-related terms—be spelled out before you sign. A VC who refuses to document core employment terms up front is a serious red flag. The authors emphasize that entrepreneurs should not be locked into exclusivity without clarity on the operative business and people terms that will govern the definitive agreements.

The chapter also cautions that term sheets sometimes carry odd or highly conditional language—“wacky conditions”—and it reminds founders that signing a term sheet is not the same as closing a deal. Building on the earlier—chapter 4’s mapping of players and mechanics and chapter 5’s clause-by-clause walkthrough of economics and control—this chapter translates technical knowledge into negotiation posture: demand clarity, watch for binding/no-shop traps, and treat any unusual conditions with skepticism. In short, understand which provisions are binding, insist on spelling out the deal points that matter to you before exclusivity kicks in, and recognize that a signed term sheet does not guarantee a completed financing.

This chapter adopts the entrepreneur’s point of view on information rights and ongoing reporting obligations that commonly appear in term sheets and investor agreements. Building on the earlier, clause-by-clause framing of venture deals, it argues that entrepreneurs should embrace transparency as a default: if you plan to take outside capital you should be prepared to deliver a budget and regular financial statements to your investors. At the same time, the chapter recognizes founder instincts to protect proprietary details and recommends pairing routine information rights with tailored confidentiality protections so sensitive data does not leak or get misused.

Entrepreneurs should negotiate scope, frequency, and format so reporting is meaningful without being crushing, and insist on confidentiality clauses when particularly sensitive operational or strategic information is involved. Chapter 9 reframes the sale-restriction debate from the entrepreneur’s point of view, arguing that the restriction on sales (the right of first refusal on common stock, or ROFR on common) is generally constructive rather than punitive. It traces the historical shift—from an older orthodoxy that prevented founders from selling until investors could exit, to the modern reality of active secondaries and longer private-company lifecycles—and concludes that ROFRs help the company control its shareholder base and comply with heightened SEC scrutiny around private transfers.

Define who qualifies as a "major investor" (so that minor or passive holders don’t gain blanket transfer control), and consider conditioning transferee rights on continued participation in subsequent financing rounds. These limits protect founders’ liquidity options while preserving the company’s ability to manage its cap table, align investor incentives, and keep downstream regulatory and governance issues manageable.

The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. While this is close enough for an example, it's not close enough for most VCs, or for most lawyers for that matter. And it shouldn't be close enough for you. chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

hurdles for entrepreneurs and their lawyers. While in some cases

Chapter 14 pulls together practical legal traps entrepreneurs routinely encounter and stresses the importance of handling certain items correctly up front. It focuses on three high‑impact areas: employment issues (most common source of lawsuits), choice of corporate structure (C Corp vs S Corp vs LLC) depending on fundraising plans, and the critical tax procedural step of filing an 83(b) election when you receive stock. The chapter is pragmatic—warning that some mistakes are merely a hassle to clean up later while others (notably failing to file an 83(b) or choosing the wrong entity when you intend to raise VC) can materially increase taxes or block future financing options.

The authors emphasize actionable takeaways: make hires explicitly "at‑will," weigh whether to include pre‑baked severance in offer letters (tradeoffs between predictability and flexibility), know that VC/angel investors generally require a C Corp (because of multi‑class stock and option mechanics), and file the 83(b) within 30 days to preserve capital gains treatment. chapter_summaries.chapter_title: CHAPTER THREE
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 15 moves from firm-level mechanics (term sheets, cap tables, convertible notes, and legal traps discussed in earlier chapters) to the place-level question: why do some places become hotbeds of startups while others do not? The chapter surveys three academic frameworks (economic agglomeration/external economies, sociology, and geography) that explain the clustering of innovation and then introduces a fourth, practice-driven framework — the Boulder Thesis — distilled from local experience. The Boulder Thesis argues that vibrant startup communities are entrepreneur-led, require long-term commitments, must be inclusive, and need ongoing activities that engage the entire entrepreneurial stack.

The chapter emphasizes the importance of a multi-decade view: community leaders must commit for the long haul (the author suggests a 20-year horizon) because startup ecosystems go through booms and busts and meaningful outcomes take time. It also stresses practical community-building: frequent, hands-on activities (hackathons, meetups, startup weekends, accelerators) that actively involve first-time and experienced founders, investors, mentors, employees, and service providers are far more impactful than occasional networking or awards events. Finally, the chapter normalizes experimentation and failure in community programs — like startups themselves, some activities will fail and should be replaced — and underscores inclusivity and continuous engagement as core to sustained entrepreneurial vitality.
